title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 19 january [1869]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 19 January [1869]
text: 19 Jan. 1873January 19Walter deari got your letter to day tuesdayTuesday with the money all safe am Obliged to you for it i thought perhaps the snow storm would prevent my getting it to day but it come and mrsMrs. Oconer sO'Connor's it is a beautifullbeautiful letter very friendly and very kind if she ever comes to new yorkNew York i hope she will come and see me and stay awhile give my love to them all) we sent hanna sHanna's box last thursdayThursday we sent it by hildreth shildreth's express i told him to pay the freight and bring the receipt or check to me and i would pay him he came that evening but brought no receipt but said he had it to the office that they generally put them there so i paid him 1â€“65 cts for the freight but have never heard whether they ever received it or not i wrote a letter to han thursdayThursday and kept it open till the express came thinking he would have a check so i could put it in the letter i sent the letter on fridayFriday morning with a list of the articles in the box if i dontdon't hear something about it to morrow i will write to heydeHeyde i shall be very sorry if she dontdon't get them georgeGeorge says he thinks itsit's all right) we sent 2 dresses and lot of muslin and flannel skirts and can of peaches and new years cake and lot of frenchFrench candy and 2 dollars in monymony and cotton and sewing silk and linings for the dresses it would be too bad if she dontdon't get them Edd says the darnddarned bugger will send em off to his sister that han wontwon't get them eddEddy is very indegnantindignant indeed i felt anxious to get them and went out one of those slusheyslushy days didentdidn't get my feet wet but got them very damp and cold and i got such a very bad cold and pain in my face i was real sick two or three days i couldentcouldn't sleep for the pain in my face saturdaySaturday night in the evening it got easeyeasy so i slept quite good and sundaySunday morning i felt better and i was very glad i did for Davis came in the forenoon and staidstayed till toward evening he staidstayed to dinner we used the new knives and castor georgeGeorge helpthelped me get dinner so we got along nicely davisDavis told georgeGeorge all about the works and a draying of the ingineengine house he had with him) georgeGeorge was much interested he is very clever he talks some of going back by the way of washingtonWashington he thinks of starting next mondayMonday i have had a letter from matt she seems to be gaining quite much i think by what she says) Jeffy is very busy she says but every thing goes on so nicely that he is very jubilant)Walter dear you spoke of sending me an atlantic if you haventhavn't sent it when you get this letter you need not georgeGeorge bought one on saturdaySaturday night he thinks your peicepiece is very fine very indeed i like it too better every time i read it) davisDavis will get one to take home)the house is progressing quite well the weather has been so good they have the second story beams laid but this bad weather is some against them but they have worked to day i beleivebelieve) georgesGeorge's men commenced to lay pipe but had to stop to day) good bie i hope you will keep well walterWalter dear i got quite down while i was sick it dontdon't take much to get mama discouraged in these days Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 19 January [1869]
